tweets.full_text:
V: how do you make open source work with your business model? 

Panelists:
* it‚Äôs very hard, trying to figure it out 
* George hotz strategy of selling something for more than it costs
* open source itself is not a moat. Need to figure it out
* marine biology has the concept of a whale fall: when a fall passes, its carcass creates a massive beautiful ecosystem, catalyses things that couldn‚Äôt exist otherwise - my fav take 

Vitalik makes a joke about ‚Äúcrypto whales‚Äù answering the call to fall üòÜ 

@johnsonmxe @VitalikButerin @gaoist @microbeminded2

tweets.full_text:
Loved this walk through of a fork of @pcaversaccio's safe hashes tool by @PatrickAlphaC @CyfrinAudits

He used @Trezor @Ledger @KeystoneWallet in the demo. I have listed the wallets in increasing order of ability to check what you are actually signing. 

Basically, don't use Trezor, Ledger may be acceptable if you don't mind doing more work, while Keystone leads the pack.

I'd like to highlight his succinctly phrased request to hardware wallets below: 

===

Dear Hardware Wallets: I have a couple of asks for you. 

#1 you should all add clear 
signing like what we saw with the 
Keystone wallet so that I can directly see what was 
going on with my transaction without having to
integrate with something like metamask

#2 it would be cool if we could export the call data so that we could match it to the tools that we write e.g.  add a QR code that allows us to scan it so we can import into where we use our tools 

#3 [that being said,] scanning QR codes is very spooky so maybe there's something more clever that you can do

#4 and if you do do a QR code have it be like a base 64 in code so you could work in offline mode

#5 additionally it would be cool if you showed the hash of the call data because that would be much easier to spot check than the entire call data 

private key attacks are the number one attack Vector from last year and they're looking like they're going
to be the number one attack vector going forward

https://t.co/av2YbrRIe3

tweets.full_text:
I struggled to understand upgradable contracts in Ethereum, and the word ‚Äúproxy‚Äù was a big reason why.

In law, a proxy HAS agency‚Äîit makes decisions on someone‚Äôs behalf. If I "appoint a proxy" to vote on my behalf as a shareholder of a public company, I let them vote however they decide is best. If I ‚Äúappoint a healthcare proxy,‚Äù I let them make decisions for me if I am unfit or unconscious.

But in Ethereum, a proxy contract HAS NO agency‚Äîit blindly forwards calls to an implementation contract using delegatecall.

This isn‚Äôt EVM devs‚Äô fault. The term proxy comes from network computing, where a proxy server relays requests without modifying them. The same idea applies to EVM proxies‚Äîthey forward calls but don‚Äôt execute logic.

Once I realized this, proxy/upgradable contracts finally clicked! Took too long. 

Let's be better about etymology, so we onboard as many ppl as quickly as possible
